citations.narrative:
The licensee has a signed program of veterinary care for the schedule, dosage and products to be used for deworming
and vaccination protocols. However, the facility is using another schedule of use for the deworming protocols that is
different than the attending veterinarian has approved in writing.
It is important that the licensee follows the approved program of veterinary care as prescribed by their attending
veterinarian. Any deviations in schedule, dosage or products from the approved attending veterinary program of care
could cause health issues or a lack of protection involving deworming or vaccinations.
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. If the licensee is going to utilize a different
schedule for deworming or vaccinations, it must be documented in writing and approved by the attending veterinarian and
kept with the program of veterinary care.
To be corrected by: October 21, 2024

The licensee does not have complete medical records on all of the dogs at the facility that includes the dates of
deworming, heart worm prophylaxis or vaccinations.
It is important to keep updated and accurate records of the worming, vaccination and heartworm prophylaxis provided and
the dates they were given to each regulated animal. The lack of complete records, including dates given could cause a
regulated animal to be over or under dosed, or missed completely in the deworming/vaccination or heartworm protocol.
Medical records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration.
To be corrected by: October 17, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee has a signed program of veterinary care for the schedule, dosage and products to be used for deworming 
and vaccination protocols. However, the facility is using another schedule of use for the deworming protocols that is 
different than the attending veterinarian has approved in writing. 
 
It is important that the licensee follows the approved program of veterinary care as prescribed by their attending 
veterinarian. Any deviations in schedule, dosage or products from the approved attending veterinary program of care 
could cause health issues or a lack of protection involving deworming or vaccinations. 
 
Each dealer, exhibitor, and research facility must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that is 
developed, documented in writing, and signed by the attending veterinarian. If the licensee is going to utilize a different 
schedule for deworming or vaccinations, it must be documented in writing and approved by the attending veterinarian and 
kept with the program of veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by: October 21, 2024 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee does not have complete medical records on all of the dogs at the facility that includes the dates of 
deworming, heart worm prophylaxis or vaccinations.  
 
It is important to keep updated and accurate records of the worming, vaccination and heartworm prophylaxis provided and 
the dates they were given to each regulated animal. The lack of complete records, including dates given could cause a 
regulated animal to be over or under dosed, or missed completely in the deworming/vaccination or heartworm protocol.  
 
Medical records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration. 
 
To be corrected by: October 17, 2024

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
 n
